perturbation.original_text: The Sellers shall not be held responsible for the delay in shipment or non-delivery, of the goods due to Force Majeure, which might occur during the process of manufacturing or in the course of loading or transit. The Sellers shall advise the Buyers immediately of the occurrence mentioned above and within fourteen days thereafter, the Sellers shall send by airmail to the Buyers a certificate of the accident issued by the competent government authorities, Chamber of Commerce or registered notary public of the place where the accident occurs as evidence thereof.
perturbation.changed_text: The Sellers shall not be held responsible for the delay in shipment or non-delivery, of the goods due to Force Majeure, which might occur during the process of manufacturing or in the course of loading or transit. The Sellers are only required to notify the buyers of the occurrence mentioned above within a reasonable time frame, if practical. The form of notification is at the sellerâ€™s discretion.
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires specific actions (immediate advice and airmail certificate within 14 days) for Force Majeure. The modified text makes the notification requirement vague and discretionary, conflicting with standard interpretations of Force Majeure clauses.
perturbation.contradicted_law: United Nations Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods (CISG) Article 79
perturbation.law_explanation: Article 79 of the CISG outlines the requirements for a party to be excused from performance due to an impediment beyond their control (Force Majeure). While it does not explicitly dictate the form or timing of notification, generally accepted principles of good faith and commercial reasonableness, implied within the CISG, suggest that notification should be prompt and adequate. The modified text contradicts this implied requirement by allowing for potentially delayed and discretionary notification, which could prejudice the buyer's ability to mitigate damages.

perturbation.original_text: All disputes in connection with this Contract or the execution thereof shall be settled friendly through negotiations. In case no settlement can be reached, the case may then be submitted for arbitration to the Foreign Economic and Trade Arbitration Committee of the China Beijing Council for the Promotion of International Trade in accordance with its Provisional Rules of Procedures by the said Arbitration Committee.
perturbation.changed_text: All disputes in connection with this Contract or the execution thereof shall be settled friendly through negotiations. In case no settlement can be reached, either party *may* unilaterally choose to litigate in a court of their choosing, regardless of jurisdiction.
perturbation.explanation: The original text mandates arbitration in Beijing. The modification allows either party to bypass arbitration and litigate in any court, contradicting the agreed-upon dispute resolution mechanism.
perturbation.law_explanation: Article 4 of the China Arbitration Law states that if parties have reached an arbitration agreement, they should apply for arbitration and cannot sue in a people's court. The modified clause directly contradicts this by allowing either party to unilaterally choose litigation despite the agreement to arbitrate, potentially rendering the arbitration agreement unenforceable in China.

perturbation.original_text: Under Letter of Credit or T/T: Under the Letter of Credit: The Buyer shall open an irrevocable letter of credit with the bank within 30 days after signing the contract, in favor of the Seller, for 100% value of the total contract value. The letter of credit should state that partial shipments are allowed. The Buyer's agent agrees to pay for the goods in accordance with the actual amount of the goods shipped. 80% of the system value being shipped will be paid against the documents stipulated in Clause 12.1. The remaining 20% of the system value being shipped will be paid against the documents stipulated in Clause 12.2. The Letter of Credit shall be valid until 90 days after the latest shipment is effected.
perturbation.changed_text: Under Letter of Credit or T/T: Under the Letter of Credit: The Buyer *may* open a letter of credit at their discretion, with the amount and terms also at their discretion. The seller will accept whatever letter of credit terms the buyer provides, or will not be paid.
perturbation.explanation: The original text stipulates the terms of the Letter of Credit (irrevocable, 100% value, etc.). The modified text gives the buyer complete discretion over the letter of credit terms, which renders the payment terms extremely vague and contradicts basic principles of contract certainty.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) Article 5 - Letters of Credit
perturbation.law_explanation: While UCC Article 5 doesn't prescribe the exact terms of a letter of credit, it does require that the terms be clear and definite. The modified text introduces so much uncertainty regarding the letter of credit's amount and terms that it becomes unenforceable, as it doesn't provide a clear basis for determining the obligations of the parties involved. It contradicts the implied requirement of certainty and good faith in commercial transactions governed by the UCC. Additionally, this creates conditions that can be seen as an unfair trade practice.
